'''Elżbieta Pleszczyńska''' (born 20 March 1933) is a [[Poland|Polish]] full [[professor]] of [[statistics]],<ref name="ipi">(in English) http://gradestat.ipipan.waw.pl/english/tworcy.html#pleszczynska</ref> activist of [[disability rights movement]].

==Biography==
M.Sc in mathematics at [[University of Warsaw]], Faculty of Mathematics, Physics and Chemistry in 1956. She held position at Institute of Mathematics [[Polish Academy of Science|PAS]] until 1972.<ref name="ipi"/> She received her Ph.D. in 1965 in the area of [[discriminant analysis]] ("Power of Test, and Separability of Hypothesis in Statistical Design of Experiments").<ref name="impan.gov.pl">(in Polish) http://www.impan.gov.pl/Rada/Awanse/dr.html</ref> Her [[habilitation]] thesis, titled "Trend Estimation Problems in Time Series Analysis", was accepted in 1973.<ref name="impan.gov.pl"/> 

In 1967/8 she was visiting researcher in [[University of Wales]] (Great Britain), and in 1971/2 in [[University of Montreal]].<ref name="ipi"/> In 1973 she moved to the Institute of Computer Science, PAS. In 1977, 1979 and 1989 she was awarded by the Polish Academy of Science.<ref name="ipi"/> In 1981 she visited [[Italy]] invited by [[Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche|CNR]].<ref name="ipi"/> In the 1990s she started (together with her team) so called [[grade data analysis]], a science of applying [[copula (statistics)|copula]] and rank methods to problems of [[correspondence analysis|correspondence]] and [[cluster analysis]] together with [[outlier]] detection.<ref>{{cite book|first=Teresa|last=Kowalczyk|author2=Elżbieta Pleszczyńska |author3=Fred Ruland |year=2004|title=Grade Models and Methods for Data Analysis with Applications for the Analysis of Data Populations|series=Studies in Fuzziness and Soft Computing|volume=151|publisher=Springer Verlag|location=Berlin Heidelberg New York}}</ref> (The adjective ''grade'' here honors statisticians of the first half of the 20th century, who called [[cumulative distribution function]]s in this way.<ref>Example: {{cite book|first=Maurice G.|last=Kendall|authorlink=Maurice Kendall|title=Rank Correlation Methods|location=London|publisher=Charles Griffin & Company Limited|year=1948|pages=108–109}}</ref>) In 1993 the [[President of the Republic of Poland]] awarded Elżbieta Pleszczyńska with the Full Professor title in the area of mathematics.<ref name="ipi"/> In 2000 she was an invited consultant of the [[Cambridge University]].<ref name="ipi"/>

In the Institute of Computer Science PAS, she had been leader of the Statistical Data Analysis division for many years. According to the Polish law, professors in PAS must retire at the age of 70.<ref>(in Polish) http://www.pan.pl/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=45&Itemid=246&limit=1&limitstart=7, art. 84, 1</ref> Retirement in 2003, although a bit confusing, didn't stop her scientific and social activity.<ref>(in English) http://www.ipipan.eu/recentpub/2004.html</ref><ref>(in English) http://www.ipipan.eu/recentpub/2005.html</ref><ref>(in English) http://www.ipipan.eu/recentpub/2007.html</ref><ref>(in English) http://www.ipipan.eu/publishing/printer/pub2008pr.html</ref>

=== Scientific views ===
Prof. Pleszczyńska is known for her criticism of the classic statistical approach. Classic [[parametric statistics|parametric methods]], like [[Pearson correlation coefficient]], or [[least squares method]] produce comparable results only for comparable distribution types (in practice [[multivariate normal distribution]] is being assumed). Parametric [[statistical test]]s are derived from distribution assumptions. Classic methods fail if the input data contain strong [[outliers]], and interpretation of their results should be different for different distribution types. In practice, the underlying assumptions are often not checked, moreover they are always violated – there is no normal distribution in the real world, because every real variable is limited (for example people cannot be –170 cm or +2 km tall), and the normal distribution implies positive [[probability density function|probability density]] for every [[real number]]. In most cases the real distribution is [[skewness|skewed]] or [[discrete distribution|discrete]], which doesn't prevent people from using normal distribution methods. The extend of this violation can be measured, but its maximum accepted level is just a convention, not mathematics. The parametric methods always work out of their conditions of use. However, their results are othen considered valid, which leads to "scientific" validation of false hypothesis. For the reasons mentioned above, Elżbieta Pleszczyńska is a strong advocate of [[explorative data analysis]]<ref>{{cite book|first=Janusz B.|last=Książyk|editor=Olaf Matyja |editor2=Elżbieta Pleszczyńska |editor3=Marek Wiech|title=Analiza danych medycznych i demograficznych przy użyciu programu GradeStat|place=Warszawa|year=2005|publisher=Instytut Podstaw Informatyki PAN, [[Children’s Memorial Health Institute|Centrum Zdrowia Dziecka]]|isbn=83-922508-0-X|pages=7 (preface by prof. Pleszczyńska)}}</ref> and [[non-parametric statistics]], like [[Spearman's rank correlation coefficient|Spearman's rho]], [[Kendall tau rank correlation coefficient|Kendall's tau]], or grade data analysis.

== Social work ==
Elżbieta Pleszczyńska has cofounded Foundation Supporting Physically Disabled Mathematicians and Computer Specialists in [[Warsaw]] (September 1990).<ref name="fund">(in English) http://www.idn.org.pl/fpmiinr_en/</ref><ref>(in Polish) http://www.idn.org.pl/fpmiinr/doeuropy5/czesc2.htm#15_lat</ref> For many years she has been the Foundation chairman.<ref>(in Polish) http://www.cs.put.poznan.pl/archiwumpti/download/Biuletyny/199103.pdf</ref><ref name="do Europy 4">(in Polish) http://www.idn.org.pl/fpmiinr/doeuropy4/brosz2000_3.htm</ref><ref name="do Europy 6">(in Polish)http://www.idn.org.pl/fpmiinr/doeuropy6/art70.html</ref><ref>(in Polish)http://fpmiinr.idn.org.pl/rada.html</ref>

The Foundation under her leadership<ref>(in Polish) http://www.niepelnosprawni.pl/ledge/x/11055</ref> is mainly interested in professional rehabilitation of physically disabled (not only mathematicians and specialists), based on computer techniques, like [[telework]].<ref name="fund"/>

Pleszczyńska has been continuously focusing attention of the public opinion on rights of disable people, in her periodical reports.<ref>(in Polish) http://www.idn.org.pl/fpmiinr/publikacje.html</ref>

== Private life ==
She has a son – journalist – and two grandchildren. She lives in Warsaw [[Wola]] district.
